section.section: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
"Correctional institution" means a place of detention or correctional confinement operated by or for the State or a local government.

"Correctional employee" means:
A person who is employed by a correctional institution; or
A person who performs duties in a correctional institution by virtue of federal, State, or local government employment.
"Court" means a district or circuit court of the State.

"Health care provider" means:
Any person, including a physician or hospital, who is licensed or otherwise authorized in this State to provide health care services and is under contract with or operated by the correctional facility; or
An employee's private physician.

text.section: The correctional institution shall collect the blood sample from the inmate, and shall have the sample tested for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) by a test and test procedure approved by the Department.

section.section:
If the inmate refuses to furnish to the correctional institution a blood sample or buccal (cheek) swab to be tested for the presence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) as required under subsection (b) of this section, a court may order the inmate to furnish the blood sample or buccal (cheek) swab if:
The correctional employee involved in the exposure or the correctional employee's representative requests the testing in writing to the State's Attorney in the county where the exposure occurred; and
The court finds probable cause to believe that the exposure occurred.

Before ordering a test under paragraph (1) of this subsection and subject to the provisions of paragraph (6) of this subsection, the court shall hold a hearing at which the correctional employee or the correctional employee's representative and the inmate or the inmate's representative have the right to be present.

The correctional employee or the correctional employee's representative and the inmate or the inmate's representative shall be notified of:
The date, time, and location of the hearing; and
Their right to be present at the hearing.

During the hearing, the court may admit into evidence only affidavits, counter-affidavits, and medical records that:
Relate to the material facts of the case; and
Support or rebut a finding of probable cause to issue a court order.

The written request of the correctional employee or the correctional employee's representative shall be:
Filed by the State's Attorney with the court; and
Sealed by the court.

Except for good cause, the court shall:
Hold the hearing within 15 days after the State's Attorney's presentment to the court of the written request of the correctional employee or the correctional employee's representative; and
Issue an order granting or denying the request within 3 days after the conclusion of the hearing.

text.section: The correctional employee shall be notified of the results of the test for the presence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) conducted under the provisions of this section.

The notification required under subsection (e) of this section shall:
Be made within 48 hours of confirmation of the inmate's diagnosis;
Include subsequent written confirmation of the possible exposure to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV); and
To the extent possible, be made in a manner that will protect the confidentiality of the correctional employee and the inmate.
If the results of the blood sample test are positive for the presence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), then the correctional employee and the inmate shall be provided appropriate counseling.
All correctional institutions shall develop written procedures to carry out the provisions of this section.
A health care provider acting in good faith to provide notification in accordance with this section may not be held liable in any cause of action related to a breach of patient confidentiality.

A health care provider acting in good faith to provide notification in accordance with this section may not be held liable in any cause of action for:
The failure to give the required notice, if the correctional employee fails to properly initiate the notification procedures developed by the correctional institution under subsection (h) of this section; or
The failure of the managing official of the correctional institution within which the correctional employee is employed to subsequently notify the correctional employee of the possible exposure to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
A health care provider may not be held liable in any cause of action related to obtaining a blood sample or performing and interpreting an approved HIV test without the inmate's informed consent.
